comments.commentBody:
General eloquent comments aside, you may have a different position if you immersed yourself in aviation flight operations protocols and concerns, aviation electrical systems, case studies in aviation accidents.
The reason civil aviation is as safe as it is is due to adherence by airlines to regulations by governing bodies like ICAO. Rules ARE based on science and safety, not just in the US but internationally.

This topic is fascinating on so many levels. It encapsulates divergent views on regulations and society.

Regulating the behaviors of others must be done with humility, not assertion of power.

The FAA it appears has at worse, failed to do their research, or at best, done a fine job or risk assessment but failed to present to the public in a convincing and candid matter what the risks are.

This far into the issue, it should not be a matter of pilot anecdotes. The many comments include compelling anecdotes that support either position.

Laws and rules are made to be broken, when they are nonsensical. Witness the flagrant law breaking during prohibition, miscegenation rules breached in the South, marijuana use in my fair state - illegal 2 months ago and legal now, demonstrating against injustice here and abroad. Breaking rules and laws should be a source of pride when the rules are arbitrary or impede freedom.

Electronics on planes can be looked at differently but generally every stupid law is defended based upon the public interest and safety, and there are always those who want bad laws and rules to remain and are indignant towards those who flaunt, disobey or ignore the rules.

Spare me folks your tired rules. Let's base decisions on solid science, not inertia.

PART 1 OF 2

Isn’t it strange the way that government spending ONLY creates jobs when the government spends money on things that KILL people and NOT when the government spends money on roads, bridges clean energy and schools?

Now the person who figures out WHY that is the case will win the Nobel Prize in Economics!

It reminds me of the Republican Talking Point that “the New Deal did not get us out of the Depression, World War II got us out of the Depression!”

I would not say that. When you think about it, War is like a force of nature. A War per se doesn’t really “do” anything. Rather, it was Roosevelt’s policy response to WWII that got us out of the Depression. If you download the numbers from:
http://www.whitehouse.gov/omb/budget/Historicals you see Federal Receipts and Outlays:

AS PERCENTAGES OF GDP
GDP (DEFICIT)
YEAR $BNs RECEIPTS OUTLAYS SURPLUS
1940 96.8 6.8 9.8 (3.0)
1941 114.1 7.6 12.0 (4.3)
1942 144.3 10.1 24.3 (14.2)
1943 180.3 13.3 43.6 (30.3)
1944 209.2 20.9 43.6 (22.7)
1945 221.4 20.4 41.9 (21.5)
1946 233.2 16.5 14.8 1.7

PART 2 OF 2
FROM TABLE 1.2 (SUMMARY OF RECEIPTS, OUTLAYS AND SURPLUSES OR DEFICITS AS PERCENTAGES OF GDP) in 1942, spending (outlays) as a % of GDP increased by 102%. In 1943, spending increased by 79%.

There is a debate as to whether or not government spending is “simulative” or “contractionary”.

Milton Friedman (an idol of many conservatives) correctly pointed out that when the Fed CUT the money supply in 1929-1930 it transformed the 1929 “Recession” into the Great Depression.

In 1932, Hoover CUT Federal Spending, making the Depression even worse.

I see no difference between the contractionary 1930 monetary policy Freidman correctly criticized, Hoover’s contractionary fiscal policy and the contractionary fiscal policy now championed by all or most Republicans.

The German philosopher Hegel sd it best 150 years ago: “The only thing that History teaches us is that Man does not learn from History.”

What we need today is the Moral Equivalent of War, to justify a bigger stimulus.

The table shows in 1942, spending increased over 1941, by 12.3 points as a % of GDP. The table shows 2009 GDP was $14,097B and 12% of that would be $1,691B or $1.7 trillion (or about $904B more than the actual $787B stimulus.)

Looked at another way, the table shows, in 2009 spending increased only by 4.3 points over 2008, as a % of GDP. If spending had increased as it did in 1942, then it would have reflected an additional 7.7 points increase or another $1.085B (i.e. $14,097B x 7.7 %)

Much of the defense budget is nothing more than a jobs program in disguise. Romney's pandering plan to "make American strong" and increase the size of the Navy was repudiated even though I'm sure all the defense contractors voted for him. Let Congress cool off for two months, then take a hard look at defense followed by real action.

Means testing also needs, finally, to be implemented. Warren Buffett said he's pleased to receive his $30K in Social Security annually, but he doesn't need it. Millions of others don't need that or Medicare, either.

Good points in your comment

I love your picture! Is that a refracted laser or regular light?
The budget is not as fat as you think it is, once 2 wars are dispensed with.

Bus drivers make a whole lot more money than the average attorney. Beyond that, your post has much merit. But what's missing is you don't know that Obama and Democrats do not want to hike taxes on folks you consider wealthy, as those rich folks line the Democrats' pockets. How did you not know that?
Senator McConnell is hardly "masterful" at negotiation.  Pompous is not the same as masterful.

I think Obama is just out of his league when he negotiates with McConnell, who is masterful.  While Obama can claim a victory of sorts, it is largely symbolic because it barely scratches the surface in producing the revenue he wants.  But now the Democrats have given up their main point of leverage aginst the Republicans who will have a much stronger hand with the debt ceiling.

The GOP and its representatives said publicly "we will not work with THIS president" before the first Obama inauguration...that's certainly petty, vindictive, and spiteful...not to mention racist and bigoted.
Nail on the head....direct hit!
Well, I suppose we will never hear that on Faux News, even though they are Fair and Balanced!

It's worth noting that a person making 500K will continue to get a tax cut on 450K and a 4% rise on 50K.....so he will pay $2000 more a year. Ouch!

Imagine living on a paltry 500K income and having it reduced by 2K! This is the kind of destruction of the wealthy which leads to total collapse.

Alter ego responds: During the longest period of prosperity, shared by all, in US history (1946 -Reagan), the top marginal rate was 70-90%. And it really destroyed the economy and jobs, didn't it?

Since Reagan, median wages have fallen over 30% while the rich have seen their incomes increase by nearly 300%, with the lowest tax rates in 50 years.

The real job creators are people who spend. Spending = jobs. Therefore, spending cuts always leads to recession and loss of jobs. Carter had a much better job creation rate than Reagan, who boosted the economy by tripling the debt (using the credit card we are still paying for); Under Reagan, unemployment rose to 10.8%, and it was only reduced by the massive borrowing.

You are wrong in too many ways to count. The House sent a bill to Senate in May, and several more in later months. Reid and Obama did zip. If you are not better informed, I can't help you. Internet is cheap and the info is out there.

I proudly voted for President Obama twice but you are incorrect.
The Fiscal Cliff was set in place back in August, when we had the Debt Ceiling Debacle and set to happen on Jan 1st, 2013, regardless as to who was elected In November.

If Romney had been elected, it would have been much worse, with Obama trying to fix BOTH the Fiscal Cliff and Gun Control before Jan 20th, only to have the new President Romney trying to reverse what he had done.

I can't help but think that this financial precipice is an artificial construct engineered by Republican cuckolds punishing the US electorate for failing to elect them to leadership.

What a bunch of sore, angry losers. What right do Republicans have to play fast and loose with the US economy and the welfare of families across the nation? Answer: None - they do it because they can. Republicans do not act in the best interests of the United States or it's citizens.

As an ex-pat and registered Republican I am so disgusted with their behavior that I am renouncing my registered status and intend to register and vote as a Democrat from here on. I do not want to be associated with this vindictive, vexatious party of losers and loonies.

In the parlance of actors - Republicans have 'lost the plot'.

TS

Let capital gains go back much closer to the Clinton rates and do not have a hard cap on charitable giving (make it a declining % of the total allowed as income rises) and I will be happier with this compromise - the big problem I see is the only time we brought in enough revenue was under the Clinton rates and we need a route back to those levels of revenue at some point.  The 20% capital gains rate still guarantees that the wealthiest will be paying less in taxes than most Americans as a percent of their income.

pt 2 (dale)
Bush II more than doubled the debt, adding up his 8 budgets. He created zero (actually lost) jobs as the US had 23 million new citizens.

Bush said that tax cuts would create jobs. Not (Romney repeated this but was rejected)! Clinton raised taxes and created 23 million jobs.

FDR pushed borrowing 30% higher than today and that led to economic disaster......Not! In fact, this borrowing/spending led to full employment which led to 30 years of shared prosperity with tax rates at the top 70-90%

Investment in job creation more than pays for itself: that is the lesson of history.
The other lesson (witness Portugal, Ireland, Spain, and Greece) is that spending cuts makes matters worse.

But people tend to ignore evidence and base their opinions on lies and myths..a projection of what they wish were true. ONly the truth will make us free.
Hope you know Obama is the sole reason for that raise---he did it by executive order.

All I know is what I have read - that 95% of small businesses earn less than $250,000. So you will not lose your tax cut in this current ...... political mess.

A business must pay taxes on its profits.
Your salary of $40,000 is a deductible item against the business profits - is it not, as it is a cost.
You must pay personal taxes on your personal income and you are entitled to the usual personal deductions against personal income - as are we all.

I am sure that you, as a small business owner, know far more than I do in this regard.
Meanwhile I shall consult with my sister who is a small business owner and I have not heard her complain as you have done in your comment here.

Your comment has made me very curious and as always there is much to be learned in every regard in our complex, financial existence.
Possibly you need a new accountant. Possibly your great reward comes when you finally sell your business.
In any case, in any situation or complex matter there is always more than meets the eye.
sorry

So this "other fellow behind the tree" must be the right wing mot du jour as it's appeared in several comments here in the last 2 days. This reminds me of when Republicans wanted to have a "serious" "adult" conversation about how "they built stuff" and how taxing the rich will pay for only a minute-and-a-half of our national debt disaster that has robbed our unborn grandchildren blind. Because anyone can get medical treatment of any kind in an emergency room and since people live healthy lives up the retirement age then gradually reduce benefits until the old folks starve to death by the side of the road. Because guns don't kill people.

Got it.
Patrick: you are right in your analysis. And "ulterior" will serve you better in the future :)
Mr. Romney lives well. He wanted to make life better for all of us. You voted against him, so you (and we) are stuck with the crumbs.
What your proposing is the idea that value is only derived from labor and not from capital. This idea is dated and disproved having been proposed in the 19th century by Marx and Engels.

The 70% to 90% tax rates you refer to were myths -- on the books, but paid but virtually nobody as a result of the availability of tax shelters.  While it's hard to think of the current tax system as straightforward, it is when compared to the 50's, 60's and 70's.

You're correct that our economy was better in the past 30 years after ww2 but what you fail to understand was this prosperity we had was because after the war this country had a competitive advantage as our industrial
centers were not bombed like they were in Europe.and not because the taxes were higher then.
Our economy now is bad for the same reason it was good in the past..
We had a competitive advantage but we failed to keep our factories up to date so we lost this competitive advantage to countries that had to rebuild from scratch and were able to build factories that were up to date with the latest technology.
Increasing taxes on what you call unearned money will just make this worse.
One more thing.
How is a heritance unearned income.
My father earned his money and paid taxes on it.
Are you saying because he died the government should take it when he wanted me to have it.

Correction:

a person making 500K will get a tax break on his first 450K and a 4% rise on the 50K above that. That means he will have a lower tax burden than if we returned to previoius tax structures. He will save more on the first 450K than he pays on the last 50K.

What is missing is raising the tax rate on unearned or passive income, which requires no work, you could be in a comma.

Work and productivity should not be taxed at all: why punish hard work. All taxes should come from unearned, passive income: inheritance, dividends, and rent.

Let's make the rich go back to work. 70% of the Forbes 400 pay 15% tax because it is all passive income. They should pay 70-90%, which has been the rate during our most prosperous years (30 years after WWII). That would move the idle rich (like Romney) to get a job to reduce their tax burden, since work should not be taxed at all.

We punish hard work and reward passive incomes. That is upside down.

You do not get it----it's all choreographed to fool us into believing any of them cares. They do not. They have fat pensions and Cadillac health care, paid for by us. They go on camera and pretend to care. They do not care, of course. They  have theirs and that is all that matters. They all get their contributions from big money, all of them. So that is what they care about. They dance for you every now and then to get your vote. Then they leave you on the floor.

The kind of casualness being displayed by the political class even on pressing issues of daily life does clearly reflect a mismatch between the people's expectations and the narrow partisan priorities of the Washington ruling establishment, turning another year ahead into social neglect and economic hardships.
Nail on the head....direct hit!
I'm sad that all of these lovely buildings are stuck facing a parking garage across the street!

woops--it was Bill and Al Gore who told us the SS money would be in a lock-box when they increased the SS tax. They didn't in fact put the cash in any sequestered account. They blew it. That's one of the elements that allows Bill to (falsely) claim a surplus. He blew the SS money. Just do your homework to confirm these facts.
He should.  I a strong Democrat will extend kudos to him. I suspect he WILL retain his speakership for enduring the most obstructionist Republican Congress ever.
The Republicans in the House virtually kicked Boehner out by crushing his "plan B".  It's likely someone else in the House is positioning to move in on the Speaker's job in his place.
Now, will Boehner pass this thing despite his right wingers? He may have to settle for a bi-partisan majority to do it. Does he have the confidence of retaining his leadership position if he does?
